qa_pairs.question: What title was conferred upon David de Stern by King Luís I of Portugal, and what was the reason cited for this honor according to the source?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>David de Stern was conferred the title of *visconde* (viscount) by King Luís I of Portugal. The reason cited for this honor was the recognition of the work of Stern's bank in floating Portuguese loans.<cite>[S7]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] David de Stern


# David de Stern



**David Jacob de Stern, Viscount de Stern** (1807 – 19 January 1877) was a German-born British banker and senior partner of the firm of Stern Brothers. [S2] ## Life and career

Stern was born in Frankfurt am Main to the prominent Stern banking family. [S3] In 1833 he moved to London and in 1844 was joined by his brother Hermann. [S4] Together, they co-founded Stern Brothers, a financial institution based in London. [S5] Stern was a member of the Commission of Lieutenancy of the City of London, and he was a director of the Imperial Bank. [S6] In 1869, King Luís I of Portugal conferred the noble title of *visconde* (viscount) on him in recognition of the work of Stern's bank in floating Portuguese loans. [S7] ## Marriage and children

Stern married Sophia Goldsmid, daughter of Aaron Asher Goldsmid, brother of Sir Isaac Goldsmid. [S8] Their son was Sydney Stern, 1st Baron Wandsworth, and their daughter Alice Theresa Lucas was a prospective Conservative Party candidate who was nearly their first woman MP. [S9] Stern died in 1877 and his wife died in 1900.

qa_pairs.question: Which member of the Goldsmid family was David de Stern's father-in-law, and how is this family related to Sir Isaac Goldsmid?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>David de Stern's father-in-law was Aaron Asher Goldsmid, as he was the father of Sophia Goldsmid, whom David married. Aaron Asher Goldsmid is related to Sir Isaac Goldsmid as his brother, making the Goldsmid family connected through their shared lineage.<cite>[S8]</cite></statement>
